entry.title: A Smarter Move from Boomi and MuleSoft to SAP Integration Suite - Assessed, Automated, Validated
entry.content:
We are living in an era of intelligent transformation, a time when the convergence of digital, physical, and biological worlds is reshaping every facet of our existence. Businesses are evolving with almost breathless speed, with enterprises expanding and adopting new applications, systems, and business models. However, this rapid evolution brings forth a surge in complexity, compelling enterprises to modernise their integration landscape in order to simplify connectivity, improve agility, and reduce operational overhead.

Imagine if your systems spoke the same language, data didnâ€™t wait in queues, processes moved with instinct, and not instruction, thatâ€™s where SAP Integration Suite takes the lead, not just as a replacement for legacy platforms but as a strategic enabler of digital transformation and landscape consolidation. It silently conducts the symphony weaving APIs, events, processes, and data into a seamless rhythm. Just flowingâ€¦.

Why Enterprises Are Making the Shift with SAP Integration Suite

Many organisations who started their journey with legacy middleware are now facing:

  • Fragmented integration landscapes across multiple middleware technologies
  • Rising costs associated with platform sprawl
  • Limited visibility and control over end-to-end processes
  • Challenges in scaling integrations across hybrid and multi-cloud environments

SAP Integration Suite provides a compelling alternative offering native integration with SAP and non-SAP systems, support for hybrid and cloud-native scenarios, and a suite of capabilities for API management, event-driven integration, and process orchestration all in one platform. Cohesion becomes essential when the architecture spans multiple middleware solutions. Consolidating your middleware landscape under one middleware platform brings tangible benefits to an enterprise as it reduces total cost of ownership(TCO) through fewer platforms to manage, maintain and operate. In SAP centric environment, moving to SAP Integration Suite has its advantages. However, the path to consolidation isnâ€™t always straightforward, especially if the customerâ€™s landscape has mature middleware platforms like Boomi and MuleSoft.

 Advantages of SAP Integration Suite over Boomi and MuleSoft

  • Smooth Migration from SAP PO/PI
    • SAP Integration Suite: Provides migration automation tool with message mapping automation from SAP PI/PO to SAP IS ensuring smoother transition.
    • MuleSoft/Boomi: No direct migration path, customers must redesign integrations from scratch
  • Pre-Package Integration content
    • SAP Integration Suite: Access to SAP API Business Hub with hundreds of pre-built integration flows (iFlows), APIs, and event packages specifically for SAP business processes.
    • MuleSoft/Boomi: Offer generic templates and accelerators but limited in-depth SAP
  • Native SAP Connectivity
    • SAP Integration Suite: Comes with pre-built adapters and deep integration with SAP applications (S/4HANA, ECC, SuccessFactors, Ariba, Concur, IBP, etc.), ensuring faster implementation and reduced customization.
    • MuleSoft & Boomi: Require third-party connectors or additional customization to integrate seamlessly with SAP landscapes.

Simplifying Migration from MuleSoft and Boomi with an End-to-End Migration Accelerator Tool

To support enterprises who are on a journey to migrate from MuleSoft and Boomi to SAP Integration Suite, we have developed a purpose-crafted accelerator that streamlines the entire lifecycle of migration from MuleSoft and Boomi to SAP Integration Suite. This tool helps assess, automate, validate, and govern migrations at scale reducing manual effort, improving accuracy, and accelerating time to value.

Hereâ€™s how it works:

Migration Assessment for MuleSoft & Boomi

  • Analyze's source artifacts (zip/process archives)
  • Identifies APIs, Processes/ Flows, connectors, and backend systems
  • Calculates integration complexity
  • Recommends equivalent SAP adapters
  • Produces a detailed PDF migration report to drive stakeholder alignment

Automated i-Flow Generation

  • Reconstructs source logic into SAP Integration Suite i-Flows
  • Uses pre-built templates for common patterns
  • Offers SAP aligned adapter recommendations through template iflows.
  • Reduces development effort by up to 30%

Mapping Logic Migration

      MuleSoft

  • Parses complex MuleSoft DWL scripts
  • Supports in conversion of DWL to Graphical mapping formats
  • Preserves nested structures and transformation logic
  • Enables plug-and-play use in SAP Integration Suite

      Boomi

  • Conversion of JavaScript to Groovy Script mapping using AI.

Validation & Testing Framework

  • Validation of migrated interfaces.
  • Compares payloads across source and target middleware and flags discrepancies.
  • Reduces test effort significantly.
  • Visual representation of the test results.

Quality Monitoring & Governance Dashboards: enhancing the existing Product monitoring capabilities

  • Provides near real-time visibility into migrated integration flows and API's enhancing the product monitoring capability
  • Customized monitoring alerts and reports of the interfaces based on filters set, through email alerts.
  • Tracks SLA compliance, error trends, and integration health at tenant level
  • AI enabled Error Info chatbot which provides potential causes if error and suggestions  to fix.
  • Version Management dashboard across all tenant in the account.
  • Certificate lifecycle management.
  • Alerting mechanism for failed transactions improving the response time of maintenance and support team.

AI Chatbot for auto documentation of Migration project

  • Generates documents (technical specification, cutover plan etc) associated with migration

So are you ready to modernize Your Middleware Landscape with SAP Integration Suite? Whether you are currently on MuleSoft or Boomi, moving to SAP Integration Suite doesn't have to be daunting. With the right approach and the right tools, you can migrate with confidence, reduce risks, and unlock a future-ready integration landscape with end-to-end automation.

Reach out to learn how we can support your middleware transformation from MuleSoft or Boomi to SAP Integration Suite.

entry.title: Driving AI Adoption with BTP: Highlights
entry.content:
A couple of days ago,  AI experts and SAP customers gathered at SAP AI Adoption Event in Barcelona to explore how Artificial Intelligence is reshaping business.

There we innovate with a fresh format designed to maximize both learning and practical engagement. The morning featured plenary sessions, where SAP leaders and experts shared the latest insights on how AI is transforming business. In the afternoon, participants had the opportunity to go deeperâ€”joining hands-on workshops and 1:1 discussions with dedicated SAP experts to explore solutions tailored to their unique challenges.

The mix of high-level perspectives and practical deep dives created an environment where strategy met execution, ensuring that every attendee left not just inspired, but equipped with actionable next steps.

Why AI Now - and Why SAP?

AI is no longer experimentalâ€”itâ€™s driving real business outcomes. Organizations need AI to boost efficiency, turn data into actionable insights, and respond proactively to changing business conditions. SAPâ€™s Business AI helps companies act faster and smarter across every function.

SAP stands out because AI is embedded in core business processes, powered by trusted, unified data, and designed for scalability and customization. This ensures reliable insights, faster decisions, and measurable impact at enterprise scale.

Why it matters?

AI adoption today determines competitive advantage. Companies that leverage AI effectively can accelerate growth, improve customer experiences, optimize operations, and achieve sustainability goalsâ€”while those that wait risk falling behind.

 

Agenda Highlights & Session recap

Welcome & Introduction

Speaker: Marc Nolla

  • Set the stage with SAPâ€™s strategic push on Artificial Intelligence
  • Challenge: What AI competitive advantage are you going to Build?

Link to presentation

Exploring the Potential of SAP BTP AI 

Speaker: Daniil Bolobonov & Marco Holzwarth

  • Explanation of our enterprise AI offering that integrates easily with your SAP systems (and also non-SAP!) to help you work smarter.
  • Architecture perspective of Joule extensibility and AI Foundation 

Link to presentation

AI Best Practices with SAP

Speaker: Alex Dalentzas

  • AI Evolution since 2016
  • Some learnings on how you can apply AI to your business processes
  • Autonomous ERP: a real case scenario
  • The relevance on an AI Architect

Link to presentation

SAP AI Portfolio and What's New

Speaker: Arthur Liebhardt

  • Sneak peek on the lastest innovations on Joule 
  • Joule Agents as the next era of business automation
  • Live demo of Generative AI Hub and Vibe Coding

Link to presentation

Hands-On Workshops

  • Four breakout room SAP BTP AI topics: 
    • Retrieval-Augmented Generation with SAP HANA Cloud
    • Automated Business Document proccessing with SAP Document AI
    • From Automation to Intelligent Business Conversations with Joule Studio
    • AI capabilities in Data and Analytics
  • Interaction with many customers and discussion on particular use cases
  • Opportunity to gain the digital badges for the hands-on
  • The portal for hands-on will be open until 2nd October 2025 for you to finish the exercises

For inquiries, please reach out to SAP BTP Adoption Workshop team: sap_btp_adoption_workshop@sap.com 

Closing Notes / Adoption and Next Steps

 Speaker: Ana Lopera

  • How to engage with your BTP CSM and move forward
  • SAP initiatives to support the AI and how can we help you to achieve it

Key Takeaways

  1. AI is delivering real business value today 
  2. Trusted, business-ready AI is essential
  3. SAPâ€™s differentiator is integration at scale 
  4. Collaboration accelerates innovation 
  5. Act now or risk falling behind 

Whatâ€™s Next?

Hereâ€™s how to keep the momentum going:

entry.title: From Penalty to Power Play: Why Identity Management Is Key to Better Customer Experiences
entry.content:
A few weeks ago, a friend bought tickets to a hockey game and wanted to transfer them to me. Like many people, we went with the quickest workaroundâ€”she shared her login credentials so I could access the tickets. But what should have been a simple process turned into several days of password resets, missed messages, and back-and-forth. By the time I finally got into her account, the tickets were gone. She had attempted to transfer them during the delay, but amid the confusion and technical issues, I never actually received them. If I had been able to log in right away, I could have just downloaded them directly. But the access issues created confusion, and without any clear support from the platform, we ended up losing the ticketsâ€”and missing the game.

It was a simple plan that fell apart because of something as basic as account access.

This experience is a small example of a much larger issue in digital commerce: the friction that arises when identity management isnâ€™t built with the customer in mind. Itâ€™s easy to overlook, but poor identity experiences lead directly to lost opportunitiesâ€”not just for consumers, but for the businesses trying to reach them.

 

Identity Friction = Lost Revenue

In todayâ€™s commerce landscape, customer expectations are sky-high. If a login process is confusing, if an account is hard to access, or if personalization feels offâ€”people walk away. And often, they donâ€™t come back.

Poor identity experiences hurt businesses in more ways than one:

  • They interrupt the buying journey. Whether itâ€™s a login loop, a forgotten password, or a complicated checkout flow, friction at these key points drives abandonment.
  • They block personalization. When customer data is fragmented across systems, itâ€™s hard to deliver the tailored experiences that todayâ€™s buyers expect.
  • They erode trust. Without clear consent management and transparency, customers hesitate to share informationâ€”or stop engaging entirely.
  • They slow down growth. Outdated systems and homegrown solutions often canâ€™t keep up with omnichannel strategies or evolving compliance needs.

For a deeper dive into how SAP CIAM can help reduce identity friction, join us at SAP TechEd on November 6 for a dedicated CIAM security session. Register here to secure your spot and learn more.

 

Where SAP CIAM + Commerce Cloud Make the Difference

Customer Identity and Access Management (CIAM) helps solve these challenges by making identity work for the customerâ€”not against them. When integrated into your commerce ecosystem, CIAM doesn't just handle sign-insâ€”it actively supports better customer relationships and business outcomes.

Hereâ€™s how:

  • It reduces friction at every stageâ€”from anonymous browsing to account creation to repeat purchases. The experience becomes smoother, simpler, and more secure.
  • It improves conversion by enabling personalized, real-time engagement without relying on clunky data handoffs or third-party cookies.
  • It builds trust by giving customers control over their data, preferences, and permissionsâ€”while helping businesses stay compliant across regions.
  • It supports scale by integrating identity across every digital touchpoint, enabling consistent experiences on web, mobile, in-store, and beyond.

In short, CIAM allows businesses to move away from fragmented, frustrating interactions and toward a unified customer experience that feels intuitive, safe, and relevantâ€”every time. To hear firsthand how SAP customers are achieving this with SAP CIAM and Commerce Cloud, join us at SAP Connect in Las Vegas on October 8. Register here to attend.

 

The Takeaway

In commerce, moments of friction are more than just annoyancesâ€”theyâ€™re missed opportunities. Whether itâ€™s lost hockey tickets or lost revenue, the cause is often the same: a broken identity experience.

Modern CIAM, especially when combined with a powerful commerce platform, turns identity into an asset. It streamlines the journey, protects the user, and empowers businesses to engage with clarity and confidence.

And the best part? It just worksâ€”so your customers donâ€™t have to. 

Learn more here.

entry.title: Joule Studio Hands-on October 16th 2025 @ ASUG-WI in Madison Wisconsin
entry.content:
Join us on October 16th in beautiful Madison, Wisconsin for the next ASUG-Wisconsin chapter meeting. 

The meeting will be held on the University of Wisconsin - Madison campus at the Pyle Center right in the heart of campus with a fantastic view of Lake Mendota. 

We have a great agenda planned and for those of you looking to get your hands-on Joule Studio in SAP Build then this is the event for you.  We will have a 3-hr hands-on session as part of this event along with a great session about Madison-based company Accuray and their journey from Microsoft Dynamics ERP to SAP S/4HANA including their use of SAP Business Technology Platform and SAP Integration Suite.

Be sure to Register NOW as there will be limited seating for the hands-on session.  

The 3-hour hands-on session will explore how Joule Studio enables developers and technical professionals to design, build, and deploy intelligent AI skills and agents within SAPâ€™s ecosystem.

Why Joule Studio?
Learn the purpose and value of Joule Studio as part of SAPâ€™s broader AI framework. Understand how it connects data, applications, and processes to deliver intelligent, context-aware solutions.

What You Can Build
Discover the wide range of possibilities with Joule Studioâ€”from automating workflows and enhancing business operations to building conversational assistants that support real-time decision-making.

Letâ€™s Build a Joule Skill (Hands-On)
Follow a guided, step-by-step exercise to create your first Joule skill. Learn how to define inputs, design logic, and test your skill in the Joule Studio environment.

Art of Creating Your Own Agents
Dive deeper into the process of designing, configuring, and orchestrating agents. Understand best practices for managing agent behaviors, optimizing performance, and ensuring seamless collaboration between skills.

Illustrative Use Cases
See how organizations are applying Joule Studio in real scenariosâ€”from HR virtual assistants and procurement insights to IT automation and operational analytics.

Resources and Next Steps
Wrap up with guidance on additional enablement materials, documentation, and community resources to help you continue developing with Joule Studio.

Join Global VP Lester Lobo and Rugved Chavan, Data Engineering and AI Specialist, as they lead us through this hands-on session.  

Register Now to join us in Madison on October 16th!

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP - Q3 2025
entry.content:
This third quarter brought some helpful innovation highlights for SAP Business Technology Platform, that weâ€™re excited to share with you! The Q3 Innobytes demonstrate the progress we made in SAP BTP over the last months. Check out the video below and explore the latest features in Application Development, Joule and more. Enjoy watching!

 

App Dev Highlights

AI-powered Capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone

In the first demo, three new AI capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone are demonstrated to help you work smarter and more efficiently.

With AI Summarization, you can create a concise summary of long documents within seconds. Simply find the content in your workspace and click Summarize to save time and work smarter.

To make engaging with content easier, you can access AI Comment Generation via the AI icon to generate contextual comments, helping respond quickly and intelligently. 

To support content creation, the AI Text Generation helps with drafting an introduction or brainstorming ideas. In the workspace editor, you can ask AI to generate Text and let it support your experience in the SAP Build Work Zone.  

Watch the demo starting at 00:09 to see these innovations in action.

Learn more

  • Blog Post SAP Build Work Zone
  • SAP Build Work Zone
  •  SAP Community

 

Skill Builder in Joule General Availability

Welcome to Joule Studio, a powerful tool that enables you to create intelligent AI agents and custom-built Joule Skills based on your specific business needs.

The creation of Joule Studioâ€™s AI agent is seamlessly integrated with SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), leveraging its robust security, scalability, and connectivity to SAP systems for maximum efficiency. In this demo, a new Joule Skill is created that automates the workflow of the badge printing process. It automatically generates and prints employee badges by integrating Joule Studio with the SAP HR database, and everything you need for this process is in one place.

Start the demo at 01:51 to get more insights.

Learn more

  • Get Started with Joule Studio
  • Detailed Tutorial
  • SAP Community Blog Page

 

Downtime-Optimized Upgrades for SAP BTP ABAP Environment

SAP BTP ABAP Environment now uses blue-green-fashioned lifecycle management to minimize the downtime during hotfixes and version upgrades.

A recent update demonstrates that switching to a new runtime takes only seconds, with release upgrades targeting about 30 minutes. This innovation aims to make the process more transparent, aligning with downtime more efficiently. With this improvement, we are minimizing downtime and optimizing upgrades! 

This demo uses an example to highlight this innovation further (starting at 03:15).

Learn more

  • SAP BTP ABAP Environment â€“ Maintenance Windows and Major Upgrade Windows in 2025

 

Integration

AI Adapter in SAP Integration Suite

In August, we released an AI adapter for Cloud Integration capability of the SAP Integration Suite on the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).

Available as part of the Standard plan and above, it allows integration flows to interact with Large Language Models, adding AI directly into the integration at runtime. In this demo iflow, a product review is analyzed with OpenAI to enrich them with customer sentiment. This example shows the detection of a negative sentiment in a product review through GPT-5. The adapter is available now for you to try.

Watch this part (starting at 04:29) to get more insights.

Learn more

  • AI Adapter Blog Post
  • AI Adapter on SAP Business Accelerator Hub

 

Data & Analytics

SQL Generation for SAP HANA in Joule

In SAP Build Code, Joule can now automatically generate SAP HANA SQL based on natural language prompts.

You can either execute it directly within the Joule panel or you can copy the SQL command into the SQL Console to perform additional operations or refinements. This integration streamlines workflows, boosts productivity, and reduces errors, eliminating manual coding and tool switching.

This is how itâ€™s done:

  1. Enable SQL generation using object definitions in your workspaceâ€™s settings
  2. Navigate to your Joule extension and select the command type HANA SQL
  3. Type your Natural Language Prompt â€“ Joule will then generate and execute the SQL for you
  4. Execute or add operations or refinements to the results

See these steps in action (starting at 05:57).

Learn more

  • Generate SQL from Natural Language using Joule

 

Cross

Modifiable Transport Requests

SAP Cloud Transport Management Service now supports Modifiable Transport Requests, allowing you to test and adjust transport requests in safe test nodes before releasing them to production.

This is how it works:

  1. Create a Modifiable Transport Request with the Create button.
  2. When opening the request, see the Tracking tab that shows the transport landscape and is now open for changes.
  3. Add content to the request and click the Test button to import directly or later and freely add or remove content.
  4. Release the request when testing is completed.

This flexible approach enables adding, removing, or redeploying content as needed, ensuring higher quality and safer deployments. Automation and Integration with other SAP BTP services are planned, so stay tuned for more to come.

To see this demo in action, watch the video (starting at 07:36).

Learn more

  • Modifiable Transport Request Blog Post

 

Cross (Cloud ALM)

Change Point Detection for Custom BTP Apps in SAP Cloud ALM

Running custom apps on SAP BTP embraces Cloud Flexibility with the Clean Core Principle. With the SAP Cloud ALM for Operations, you can monitor SAP and non-SAP applications end-to-end. This feature ensures business continuity and operational efficiency.

Real User Monitoring gives you clear insights into usage by tracking executions, performance, and response times all in one interface. 

If the performance suddenly shifts, Change Point Detection identifies unusual patterns in the performance compared to historical trends. You can then directly navigate to the respective request and even receive alerts or emails when a change point is detected. This helps quick investigation of the issue and ensures smooth operations.

This new feature is highlighted (starting at 08:52).

Learn more

  • SAP Cloud ALM for Operations Expert Portal
  • SAP BTP Developerâ€™s Guide (Github)
  • Join us for TechEd:
  • CS101 | Discover SAP Cloud ALM for operations in action
  • CS261 | Monitoring a custom SAP BTP application with SAP Cloud ALM for operations

 

Share your thoughts 

These videos are for YOU, and we would love to hear your impressions. How do you like the video? How can we improve the upcoming videos? Please share your feedback by liking this post or leaving a comment below.

Thank you for your support and happy viewing, sharing, and enjoying!

You Might Also Be Interested In

  • SAP BTP Garage: monthly LIVE webinar with hands-on use case walkthroughs and demos.
  • Unlocking SAP BTP: monthly podcast covering all things SAP BTP.

entry.title: Why Clients Say No to BTP â€“ and How to Change Their Mind
entry.content:
Hey BTP Community! Do you know that feeling? You walk into a meeting with an innovative idea, and the clientâ€”just hearing "SAP BTP"â€”immediately rejects it. "I don't want BTP implementation!" â€“ they exclaim, with a look of weariness in their eyes.

Too many times, innovation, instead of solving problems, becomes... a hot potato.

Sure, there are companies boasting a full migration to BTP, but the truth is, most organizations have concerns. Concerns about the new, about the cost, about too much detachment from the stable, "on-premise" world.

But today, I'll show you how to turn that "No" into "Why didn't we do this sooner?" I'm presenting a true case that proves, in certain scenarios, BTP is not just better; it's the only sensible and secure solution.

End Customers Straight into S/4HANA

Problem Analysis: When On-Premise "Knowledge and Familiarity" Becomes the Biggest Risk.

Imagine a typical scenario: A client needs a portal where their end customers (B2C/B2B) can verify the status of their service requests (or other object/s existing in the S/4HANA).

On-premise decision: We create external user accounts directly in the S/4HANA system. We define roles just like for internal users. We have advanced control and know the system inside out. Sounds good, right?

This approach, while familiar, introduces critical risks and burdens:

  1. Security Risk: This is my biggest headache. An external user, even with the most restrictive role, works on the same system as critical business processes and your internal employees. There is a risk (or its perception) that the user will gain access to data they shouldn't. This discomfort is a real threat to your company.

  2. Performance Issues: Suddenly, your customers start working on the same system as your business processes! Increased traffic, planned jobs, mass status verifications... all of this burdens S/4HANA. Planning for increased resource consumption is required.

  3. Additional Team Workload: Every request regarding access problems, passwords, or end-customer permissions lands on your Security/Basis team's desk. This burdens them, diverting them from key maintenance and development tasks.

The "SAP Plumber" Architecture: Why Are Customers Waiting in the Dark?

This scenario was further complicated by inefficient integration processes:

  1. The Customer creates a request in an old, external Legacy System (Success - 200 - Request Created in the Lagacy System).
  2. The request is saved in the Legacy Database (Status: "Staging").
  3. The Legacy System processes requests and transfers them (via API) to S/4HANA at intervals.

And here the drama begins:

  • S/4HANA REJECTS some requests for various reasons (business rules, technical errors, missing data).
  • The client receives no feedback. They just wait. And then they wait some more.
  • Finally, the request lands on the servisk desk of... System Maintenance Experts! (Our "SAP Plumber" ðŸ”§). They painstakingly verify errors, push through messages, and waste valuable time on tasks that should be automated.

The result? Low customer satisfaction, increased pressure, and prioritization of requests that were never even processed in the first place!

 The Solution You Need: Client Portal on SAP BTP

Isolation, Visibility, Scalability â€“ The Three True Benefits of BTP.

Client portals are an ideal, canonical use case for SAP BTP!

How does it work, technically and business-wise?

1. Isolation and Security 

  • We deploy a new Portal Application (e.g., based on SAP CAP in Node.js or Fiori/UI5) on SAP BTP.
  • End customers log in ONLY to BTP. Their accounts, users, and traffic are completely isolated from the critical S/4HANA system
  • Key logic and statuses are handled outside the ERP, in a secure BTP environment.

 

 

2. Full Request Status Visibility

  • The BTP application integrates with the Legacy system. Since SAP CAP is Node.js, we can:

    •  

      Consume existing Legacy APIs.
    • Or, if no API exists, connect directly to the Legacy Database (using the appropriate driver).
  • From the moment a request is created, the client sees its FULL and CURRENT status, directly in the BTP application.
  • (Such app is also helpfull for technical persons)
  • S/4HANA Integration: If necessary, we use secure OData APIs from S/4HANA (read-only or controlled write access) to fetch additional, approved information (e.g., invoice number, agent name). Controlled APIs are your gateway, not an open door!

3. Unleashing Data Potential

  • A bonus that is often overlooked: If we decide to use HANA DB on BTP, we automatically gain the ability to easily consume and analyze data from the Client Portal in analytical tools such as SAP DataSphere, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), or Business Data Cloud (BDC).

  • Creating reports, tracking progress, measuring satisfaction, and identifying bottlenecks becomes trivially simple.

Break Client Resistance. Turn "No" into "I Need This."

A client who says "No to BTP" is actually saying:

  • "I don't want additional costs."
  • "I don't want complications."
  • "I don't understand how this will help me."

My answer:
"BTP is not an end goal; BTP is a tool that eliminates critical architectural and business risks."

When integration is so strongly tied to the SAP S/4HANA ecosystem, and the requirements are data isolation and scalability â€”  SAP BTP is good choice.

Leave Kudos if You like it ðŸ™‚

entry.title: Step-by-Step: Implementing Generative AI with SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction:

This blog walks through building an AI Sales Assistant on SAP HANA Cloud calculation views. The assistant enables users to ask natural-language questions such as â€œWhich product category had the highest sales in Q2?â€ and receive contextual answers generated directly from enterprise data.

The solution uses the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pattern, where sales transactions stored in HANA are enriched with embeddings and combined with a Large Language Model (LLM) to deliver precise, business-aware responses. This approach extends the analytical power of HANA Cloud with conversational intelligence- effectively bringing AI integration to your calculation views without moving the data out of HANA.

Weâ€™ll cover the concepts, high-level architecture, and detailed implementation steps so you can replicate this setup on your own HANA Cloud system and make the most of your existing calculation views.

High Level Architecture:

Key Concepts:

Retrieval-Augmented Generation:

Itâ€™s an AI pattern where a language model (like GPT) is not used in isolation, but is â€œaugmentedâ€ with external knowledge retrieved from a database or document store.

It has two main steps:

  1. Retrieval â€“ Find the most relevant documents/data from a knowledge source (e.g., database, embeddings index, vector store).

  2. Generation â€“ Pass both the retrieved data + the userâ€™s query into the LLM so the response is grounded in actual facts instead of just relying on the LLMâ€™s training data.

SAP HANA Cloud:
The foundation of this project is SAP HANA Cloud. HANA calculation view serves as the source for the RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) application. With the new HANA Cloud Vector Engine, we can now store and query embeddings directly inside HANA eliminating the need for external vector databases. For this setup, we create a dedicated embeddings table to persist vector representations of the sales data.

Flask API:
For the backend, I used Flask, a lightweight Python web framework.Flask allows Python code to be exposed as REST APIs or lightweight web applications. In this project, the Flask API connects to the HANA calculation view, retrieves data, and interacts with the OpenAI API. OpenAI generates embeddings for the data, which are then stored in the embeddings table in HANA Cloud. The same API also handles user prompts: it takes queries from the frontend, searches the embeddings table, and returns contextual answers. 

Streamlit:
The frontend is built with Streamlit, a Python framework for creating simple yet powerful user interfaces. It provides a chat-like interface where users can enter questions. The prompts are passed to the Flask API, which handles retrieval and reasoning. While Streamlit makes prototyping easy, this frontend could also be replaced with SAP Fiori or any Web frontend.

Implementation steps:

Letâ€™s see step by step on how to develop this framework for existing calculation views.

Prerequisites: Python 3.9+, BAS environment, CF CLI, HANA DB instance, OpenAI API key.

  1. I have two projects in BAS: one containing the HANA calculation views, and the other containing the Flask backend (referred to as the Flask app). Below is the output of the calculation view.

        2.We need to convert the hana data into embeddings and store them in HANA tables. Create embeddings table in HANA cloud. Below is the sql for that. 

CREATE TABLE SALES_EMBEDDINGS (
    TRANSACTION_ID NVARCHAR(50),
    TEXT NVARCHAR(5000),
    EMBEDDING REAL_VECTOR(1536)
);

       3. To generate embeddings using a LLM we need access. In my case i have used LLM from Open AI. Create an account in Open AI and register for Open API key.

       4. Create a python file (eg : generate_embeddings.py) in your flask project to generate embeddings based on your calculation view data and store in HANA cloud table created above. Have your credentials in the env file for testing. Make sure your BAS dev space is in the same region as your HANA cloud instance otherwise connection fails.  This step makes sure we are able to connect to HANA convert calculation view(CV) data into text and generate embeddings for it. Run this file separately and see if data is inserted into HANA cloud table.

import os
from hdbcli import dbapi
from openai import OpenAI
from dotenv import load_dotenv

# Load environment variables
load_dotenv()

# OpenAI client
client = OpenAI(api_key=os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY"))

# Connect to SAP HANA Cloud
conn = dbapi.connect(
    address=os.getenv("HANA_HOST"),   # e.g. yourhana.hana.prod-us10.hanacloud.ondemand.com
    port=int(os.getenv("HANA_PORT", "443")),
    user=os.getenv("HANA_USER"),
    password=os.getenv("HANA_PASSWORD")
)

cursor = conn.cursor()

# Fetch sales transactions
cursor.execute("""
    SELECT TRANSACTION_ID, REGION, PRODUCT, SALES_AMOUNT, SALE_DATE 
    FROM schema name."cv_sales_test"
""")
rows = cursor.fetchall()

# 5. Generate embeddings and insert into HANA
for row in rows:
    transaction_id, region, product, sales_amount, sales_date = row
    text = f"Transaction {transaction_id} in {region} sold {product} for {sales_amount} on {sales_date}"

    embedding = client.embeddings.create(
        model="text-embedding-3-small",
        input=text
    ).data[0].embedding

    cursor.execute("""
        INSERT INTO "schemaname"."SALES_EMBEDDINGS" (TRANSACTION_ID, TEXT, EMBEDDING)
        VALUES (?, ?, ?)
    """, (transaction_id, text, embedding))

conn.commit()
cursor.close()
conn.close()

print("Embeddings inserted into SALES_EMBEDDINGS table in HANA Cloud.")

Sales embeddings table output:

       5. Now let's implement RAG on embeddings. Create a new file for RAG query code. This function connects to HANA cloud and fetches stored vector representations of the transactions. The user's question is passed to OpenAI embeddings API and question is converted into numerical vector. We compute cosine similarity between the query embedding and stored transaction embeddings. The top results are combined with the userâ€™s original question to form a prompt, which is then sent to the LLM to generate a contextual answer.

import os
import json
import struct
import numpy as np
from hdbcli import dbapi
from openai import OpenAI
from sklearn.metrics.pairwise import cosine_similarity
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv()


# --------------------------
# Get HANA credentials (VCAP aware)
# --------------------------
def get_hana_credentials(debug=False):
    vcap_services = os.environ.get("VCAP_SERVICES")
    if vcap_services:
        try:
            vcap = json.loads(vcap_services)
            for key in vcap:
                if "hana" in key.lower():  # find any hana service
                    creds = vcap[key][0]["credentials"]
                    if debug:
                        print("Found HANA credentials from VCAP_SERVICES:", creds)
                    return {
                        "host": creds.get("host"),
                        "port": creds.get("port"),
                        "user": creds.get("user"),
                        "password": creds.get("password")
                    }
        except Exception as e:
            if debug:
                print("Error parsing VCAP_SERVICES:", e)

    # fallback to env vars
    creds = {
        "host": os.environ.get("HANA_HOST"),
        "port": os.environ.get("HANA_PORT"),
        "user": os.environ.get("HANA_USER"),
        "password": os.environ.get("HANA_PASSWORD")
    }
    if debug:
        print("Using HANA credentials from environment variables:", creds)
    return creds

# --------------------------
# Run RAG query
# --------------------------

def run_rag_query(user_query, top_k=5, debug=False):

    openai_api_key = os.environ.get("OPENAI_API_KEY")
    if not openai_api_key:
        raise Exception("OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable not set")
    openai_client = OpenAI(api_key=openai_api_key)

    hana_creds = get_hana_credentials(debug=debug)
   
    conn = None
    cursor = None
    try:
        conn = dbapi.connect(
            address=hana_creds["host"],
            port=int(hana_creds["port"]),
            user=hana_creds["user"],
            password=hana_creds["password"]
        )
        cursor = conn.cursor()

        # Fetch embeddings from HANA
        cursor.execute('SELECT TRANSACTION_ID, TEXT, EMBEDDING FROM "schemaname"."SALES_EMBEDDINGS"')
        rows = cursor.fetchall()

        if not rows:
            context = "No transactions available."
        else:
            # Compute query embedding
            embedding_resp = openai_client.embeddings.create(
                model="text-embedding-3-small",
                input=user_query
            )
            query_embedding = np.array(embedding_resp.data[0].embedding, dtype=np.float32)
            query_dim = len(query_embedding)

            texts, embedding_list = [], []
            for row in rows:
                text = row[1]
                blob = row[2]
                if len(blob) < query_dim * 4:
                    continue
                embedding = np.array(struct.unpack('f' * query_dim, blob[:query_dim*4]), dtype=np.float32)
                texts.append(text)
                embedding_list.append(embedding)

            if not embedding_list:
                context = "No valid transactions found."
            else:
                similarities = [cosine_similarity(query_embedding.reshape(1, -1), e.reshape(1, -1))[0][0] for e in embedding_list]
                top_indices = np.argsort(similarities)[-top_k:][::-1]
                context = "\n".join([texts[i] for i in top_indices])

        # GPT completion: summarize transactions
        prompt = f"""
You are a helpful sales analyst assistant.
Based on the following transactions:

{context}

Answer the user's question in **natural language**, summarizing key insights if possible.
Question: {user_query}
Please keep your answer concise.
"""

        response = openai_client.chat.completions.create(
            model="gpt-4o-mini",
            messages=[{"role": "user", "content": prompt}]
        )

        return response.choices[0].message.content.strip()

    except Exception as e:
        return f"Error in run_rag_query: {str(e)}"

    finally:
        if cursor:
            cursor.close()
        if conn:
            conn.close()

 

       6.  Wrap the above RAG query code in a function and use it in Flask. Install Flask if not already available. Now Flask API is directly using RAG logic. Frontend application can call this API and get a response. Ensure the Flask API works locally and returns expected results before deploying to Cloud Foundry.

pip install flask

 

from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
from hdbcli import dbapi
from openai import OpenAI
import numpy as np
import struct
import os
import json
from sklearn.metrics.pairwise import cosine_similarity as sk_cos_sim
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv()

app = Flask(__name__)

# --------------------------
# Cosine similarity
# --------------------------
def cosine_similarity(a, b):
    norm_a = np.linalg.norm(a)
    norm_b = np.linalg.norm(b)
    if norm_a == 0 or norm_b == 0:
        return -1
    return np.dot(a, b) / (norm_a * norm_b)

# --------------------------
# Get HANA credentials
# --------------------------
def get_hana_credentials():
    vcap_services = os.environ.get("VCAP_SERVICES")
    if vcap_services:
        try:
            vcap = json.loads(vcap_services)

            # Look for a service whose name includes "hana"
            for service_name, service_defs in vcap.items():
                if service_name.lower() == "hdi_db":
                    creds = service_defs[0]["credentials"]
                    host = creds.get("host")
                    port = creds.get("port")
                    user = creds.get("user")
                    password = creds.get("password")

                    if host and port and user and password:
                        print(f"Using HANA service from VCAP: {service_name}")
                        return {
                            "host": host,
                            "port": port,
                            "user": user,
                            "password": password
                        }
                    else:
                        print(f"HANA service in VCAP missing user/password. Falling back to manual env vars.")

        except Exception as e:
            print(f"Failed to parse VCAP_SERVICES: {e}")

    # Fallback to manual env vars
    print("Using manual HANA_* environment variables")
    return {
        "host": os.environ.get("HANA_HOST"),
        "port": os.environ.get("HANA_PORT"),
        "user": os.environ.get("HANA_USER"),
        "password": os.environ.get("HANA_PASSWORD")
    }

# --------------------------
# RAG query
# --------------------------
#
# " Your RAG Query here"

# --------------------------
# Health check route
# --------------------------
@app.route("/")
def index():
    return "Flask API is running!"

# --------------------------
# Query route
# --------------------------
@app.route("/query", methods=["POST"])
def query_rag_route():
    data = request.get_json()
    user_query = data.get("query", "")
    if not user_query:
        return jsonify({"error": "Query missing"}), 400

    # Run RAG query
    results = run_rag_query(user_query, top_k=5, debug=False)

    # Return in a format that Streamlit expects
    return jsonify({"results": results})

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True, host="0.0.0.0", port=int(os.environ.get("PORT", 5000)))

Once you run flask API code ,it will start REST API server. It should return "Flask API is running".

http://<your-BAS-workspace-url>:5000/query

        7. Deploy the Flask app on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry and you will see a URL assigned. Deploying it on cloud foundry frees the dependency on BAS dev space and our frontend app can always call the Flask API. Bind it to the HANA service instance so that cloud foundry injects credentials into the app's environment (VCAP_SERVICES) so the running code can connect to HANA. This makes sure our Flask API will have HANA credentials at runtime. After binding check environment and logs.

Check for services and push your app to CF.

cf services
cf push "app name" -f manifest.yml

For binding app to HANA service:

cf bind-service "app name" "hana service"
cf restage "app name"

Verify environment and logs

cf env "your app name"
cf logs "your app name" --recent

Test it using curl. See the response in results section.

       8. For UI, I have implemented using streamlit on my local machine. In Command line run 'pip install streamlit requests' . Run the program file that contains the code. 

Your browser will open at :

http://localhost:8501

 

Type in any question and it will return a contextual response like below.

Key Advantages:

Leverage Existing SAP Data assets- Reuse of existing HDI Containers and calculation views.

Secured and Enabled -  Access to HANA data remains within the SAP security framework.

Scalable and extensible - The architecture can support multiple use cases like Finance, HR, and Logistics.

Enhanced insights - Combines structured data retrieval with natural-language summarization.

Conclusion:

By integrating SAP HANA Cloud with a Large Language Model using the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) approach, weâ€™ve transformed standard calculation views into an AI-powered sales assistant . This demonstrates how modern AI capabilities can be layered on top of established enterprise data systems, opening the door to smarter, faster, and more interactive business decision-making.

Thank you,

Saravanan Chinnaswamy.

entry.title: Test Automation Solution for PO7.5 to SAP Integration Suite Migration
entry.content:
Test Automation Solution for PO 7.5 to SAP Integration Suite Migration

Enterprises are transitioning away from legacy SAP Process Orchestration (PO) towards SAP Integration Suite as PO approaches end of life. While this migration promises better scalability and integration capabilities, it also brings a significant challenge of ensuring data consistency and integrity throughout the process without disrupting business users.

In any migration project, testing can consume around 40% to 50% of the overall effort if done manually. Manual testing is time-consuming and prone to human error. Complex interfaces, multiple test cases, and large volumes of data drives up the time and cost of testing. Thoroughly validating that the new environment behaves as expected is critical to a successful transition. This is where automated testing solutions comes into play, simplifying and accelerating the validation of migrated interfaces.

 We have built a test tool to extract, compare, and validate payloads between your legacy PO system and SAP Integration Suite. This tool simplifies and automates testing of migrated iFlows, making your transition smoother, faster, and more reliable.

Key Features of Our Test Automation Tool

  • Automates payload extraction from SAP PO 7.5: Extracts input and output messages from your existing PO environment. It establishes connectivity with the PO System and pulls the payload for testing.
  • Validates test cases directly against migrated flows in Cloud Integration : Run test scenarios on the target platform(SAP Integration Suite) to verify correctness of migration.
  • Compares output payloads across systems: Detect any mismatches or errors.
  • Supports various testing approach: Whether testing single or multiple interfaces, Our tool adapts to project needs. It supports regression testing.
  • Generates detailed, downloadable test reports: Gain visibility into test results with comprehensive  reports.
  • Alerts via mails in case of failures: Immediate notifications enable quick corrective actions.
  • Supports standard adapters.
  • Monitoring through quality management and governance dashboard.

Whether you are migrating a few interfaces or hundreds, test tool brings efficiency, visibility, and reliability to your testing process saving both time and cost.

Integrating our test automation tool into your migration strategy will help with:

  • Faster testing cycles that reduce the overall migration timeline.
  • Improved reliability with consistent, repeatable automated test runs.
  • Greater visibility into testing outcomes through detailed reports.
  • Enhanced confidence that migrated interfaces behave exactly as expected.
  • Scalability to handle migrations involving just a few interfaces or hundreds.

Ready to accelerate your PO migration testing during migration? Reach out to learn how our tool can simplify your migration from PI/PO to SAP Integration Suite and save time, reduce costs, and ensure a smooth migration.

entry.title: Integrating SAP Document Information Extraction (Document AI) with SAP CAP â€“ Step by Step
entry.content:
Introduction :

In the SAP ecosystem, extracting meaningful data from documents such as invoices, contracts, or delivery notesâ€”especially in accounting, finance, and operational processesâ€”is often a manual and time-consuming task.Since these documents are usually in PDF or scanned image formats, using traditional data processing methods to identify fields is both error-prone and unsustainable in the long run.This is where SAP Document AI comes into play.By leveraging AI-powered models, Document AI can automatically analyze documents and extract key fields such as invoice number, date, currency, supplierâ€“customer information, and line items.This eliminates the need for manual data entry, making the overall process faster, more reliable, and significantly more efficient.In this blog post, I will walk you through the step-by-step process of enabling SAP Document AI on SAP BTP and integrating it with a CAP (Cloud Application Programming) project.Starting from service activation, weâ€™ll cover creating a service key, performing authentication (token retrieval), defining actions in CAP, uploading files, and storing the extracted Document AI results in a database.By the end of this guide, youâ€™ll have a fully functional CAP endpoint that can be tested via Postman.Youâ€™ll learn how to send real PDF invoice files to Document AI and receive structured data in returnâ€”a foundation you can later extend with UI5 interfaces or workflow integrations.


Step 1 â€” Creating the Document AI Service in SAP BTP

First, we need to enable the Document AI service in SAP BTP. To do this:

  1. Log in to your SAP BTP subaccount.
  2. Open the Service Marketplace .
  3. Find the SAP Document AI Trial service under the Artificial Intelligence category .

On the service details page, you'll see the Overview and Service Plans tabs. Click Create to create a service instance .

Select the default plan . This plan enables basic API access in a trial environment and creates the instance your CAP project needs to connect to the Document AI service.

Fill out the form below:

  1. Service: SAP Document AI Trial Version
    â†’ We will be using this service. Since it is a trial version, we will use the free trial quota.

  2. Plan: default
    â†’ Only the default plan is available in the trial environment. It is sufficient for basic use.

  3. Runtime Environment: Cloud Foundry
    â†’ Defines where the service will run. Cloud Foundry is often chosen for integration with CAP projects.

  4. Domain: dev
    â†’ Select the Cloud Foundry domain where your project is located (for example, dev, test).

Instance Name: DocAI
â†’ You can give the service instance any name you want. This makes it easier to connect later (you can use lowercase, for example docai).

After filling in all the fields, you can click the Next button to proceed to the confirmation screens and complete the sample creation process.

Once the instance has been successfully created, the next step is to generate a Service Key for it . This key contains the authentication information needed for your CAP project to connect to the Document AI service.

  • Click the ellipsis ( â€¦ ) on the far right of your sample row .

  • Select Create Service Key from the menu .

In the dialog box:

 

  •  

    • In the Name field, enter a meaningful name such as DocAIKey .

    • You can leave the other settings at their default values.

    • Then click Create .

  • Once the Service Key is generated, click on its row to open the detail page.

After copying the JSON:

Adding Service Key details to the file To access .envthe Document AI service, we need to define credentials in our CAP project. To do this,
you can add a structure like the following to the file located in your project's root directory:.env

Correct the highlighted errors and try again.

Unsupported HTML code has been removed from your message. The HTML has been updated. Please review the message and send it when you are satisfied.

{
  "DOCAI_CLIENT_ID": "xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
  "DOCAI_CLIENT_SECRET": "xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
  "DOCAI_TOKEN_URL": "https://39c50baetrial.authentication.us10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token",
  "DOCAI_URL": "https://aiservices-trial-dox.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com/document-information-extraction/v1"
}

In real projects , instead of manually adding these details to the file .env, service keys are automatically linked to the application. This way, the application reads credentials from environment variables ( ) and is managed more securely. Automatic linking can also be achieved during deployment via MTA or manifest files VCAP_SERVICES.

service.cdsAction Definition in File

using { app as db } from '../db/schema';

service InvoiceService {
  entity Invoices as projection on db.Invoices;
  entity InvoiceItems as projection on db.InvoiceItems;

  action analyzeAndSave(file : LargeBinary, filename : String) returns {
     documentNumber : String(60);    
    documentDate   : Date;           
    currencyCode   : String(3);      
    senderName     : String(255);    
    receiverName   : String(255);   
    netAmount      : Decimal(15,2);  
    taxName        : String(40);     
    taxRate        : Decimal(5,2);   
    taxAmount      : Decimal(15,2);  
    grossAmount    : Decimal(15,2);  

  };
}

First, we define a CAP Action to send the PDF to the Document AI service and retrieve the result . This action can be triggered from the frontend or from tools like Postman.

For example, let's define an action with the following name :analyzeAndSave

  • filefield: Retrieves PDF file content in Base64 format.

  • filenamefield: Contains the file name.

  • returnssection: Returns key invoice fields from the AI â€‹â€‹service (for example, documentNumber, documentDate, currencyCode, etc.).

This step creates the backend point that will trigger access to the Document AI service.

At this point, we need to listen for the action we defined in the backend . To do this , we add an event handler to . When the action is triggered, this handler sends the file to the Document AI service, retrieves the analysis result, and saves it to the database. The entire flow is managed within this function.analyzeAndSaveservice.cdssrv/service.js

module.exports = cds.service.impl(function () {
  this.on("analyzeAndSave", async (req) => {
    // We define the **helper functions required for the Document AI integration**.

  });
});

 

Obtaining a Token (Authentication)
Now that we've defined the service credentials in the file.env, we need to obtain an access token to send requests to the Document AI service.We'll add the following sample functionto our file:
getTokensrv/service.js

const axios = require("axios");

async function getToken() {
  const r = await axios.post(
    process.env.DOCAI_TOKEN_URL,
    new URLSearchParams({
      grant_type: "client_credentials",
      client_id: process.env.DOCAI_CLIENT_ID,
      client_secret: process.env.DOCAI_CLIENT_SECRET,
    }),
    { headers: { "Content-Type": "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" } }
  );
  return r.data.access_token;
}

This function access_tokenreturns a value from the SAP Document AI service using the information in the file. This token will be used in subsequent API calls within the Authorization header ..env

In real projects, this step is often automated through target+service binding . The CAP application reads the necessary information VCAP_SERVICESfrom environment variables to obtain the token .

In this step, we retrieve the schemas defined in Document AI and
select the appropriate one for invoices. This allows the model to determine which fields to extract (e.g., Invoice ID, Date, Currency, etc.).

const schemas = await fetchSchemas(base, token);
console.log("[DocAI] schemas count =", schemas.length);

const chosen = pickInvoiceSchema(schemas);
if (!chosen) return req.error(500, "No invoice-related schema available in DOX");
console.log("[DocAI] chosen =", chosen);

 

    • fetchSchemas: Retrieves the schema list from DOX using the access token.

    • pickInvoiceSchema: Selects the schema whose name is invoice or contains the invoice .documentType

    • If none are found, return 500 (an obvious error to the developer).

    Base64 â†’ Buffer conversion (prepare the file)
    The PDF file received from the client (UI5/Postman) may be in Base64 format. If it is a Data URL (for example,data:application/pdf;base64,...), remove the prefix and convert it to a true binary buffer.

let b64 = Buffer.isBuffer(file) ? null : String(file);
if (b64 && b64.startsWith("data:")) {
  const i = b64.indexOf("base64,");
  if (i > -1) b64 = b64.slice(i + "base64,".length);
}
const buffer = Buffer.isBuffer(file) ? file : Buffer.from(b64 || file, "base64");
console.log("[CHECK] filename=", filename, "buffer length=", buffer?.length);
if (!buffer?.length) return req.error(400, "Empty or invalid base64 file");

 

    • The field we will send via HTTP form-data needs to be binary ; therefore we convert the Base64 payload into a buffer .file

    • We return 400 (client error) for an empty or corrupt file .

    Create a job (submit with schemaId) We provide the selected schema and document type in , then submit the file to DocAI to start.
    options

const options = {
  clientId: "default",
  schemaId: chosen.id,
  documentType: chosen.documentType || "invoice",
};
console.log("[DocAI] submit options =", options);

const submitted = await submitJob(base, token, buffer, filename || "invoice.pdf", options);
const jobId = submitted?.id;
if (!jobId) throw new Error(`Job submit failed: ${JSON.stringify(submitted)}`);
console.log("[DocAI] jobId =", jobId);

    • schemaId: chosen.idâ†’ we use a dynamic schema id.

    • If successful, it returns a jobId; we use this ID to track the status of the job.

    • If filenamenot provided the default value is "invoice.pdf".

    Question the work and get results

    • The job runs in the background. We poll at intervals until the status is COMPLETED .

    • Once the process is complete, the extracted areas become available under .extraction

const result = await pollJob(base, token, jobId, 60000, 1500);
console.log("[DocAI] status DONE, extraction keys =", Object.keys(result?.extraction || {}));

    • pollJob(base, token, jobId, 60000, 1500)â†’ 60 sec timeout / 1.5 sec interval .

    • Below and result.extractionyou get .headerFieldslineItems

    NOW LET'S GO TO TESTING:

    First, ...

cds watch --profile hybrid

Let's start our CAP project with the following command. (I started it this way because I chose HANA as the database .)

Sample Invoice PDF file:

 

Above is a sample PDF file we sent to the SAP Document AI service. The service automatically analyzes the invoice and extracts fields such as the invoice number, date, currency, supplier-customer information, and item information.

Testing with Postman:
Now that everything is ready on the backend, we can test the CAP action integrated with the Document AI service. To do this, use a REST client like Postman and send the following request:

  • Method: POST

    URL: http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/invoice/analyzeAndSave

    Body (JSON):

    • file name: Name of the PDF file to be uploaded

    • file: PDF file content in Base64 format

    In this answer:

    • The fields extracted by Document AI match exactly the action return types defined in service.cds.

    • These values â€‹â€‹are also automatically saved to the HANA database in the background.

    In real projects, this setup isn't written manually. Instead, the Document AI service automatically connects to the CAP application via service binding . The application reads the necessary credentials directly from environment variables, and token acquisition is performed automatically in the background. This not only increases security (sensitive data like client secrets aren't visible in the code or repository) but also allows the application to run across different environments (dev, test, production) without additional configuration . During deployment, binding is provided via MTA or manifest files, and the application continues to run seamlessly with the same approach when deployed to production..envVCAP_SERVICES

 

Optional: Storing Raw Document AI JSON for Debugging:

 
 

In the Invoices entity of the schema , I defined a field called to store the original response returned by the Document AI service. This field is of type LargeString and holds all the header and line item data returned by Document AI in JSON format.RawJson

The purpose of this area:

  • Debug/Trace : Easily inspect the data returned by Document AI during development.

  • Extensibility : If I later want to add new fields or change the mapping structure, I can access the original source.

  • Data Traceability : Store raw invoice data so it can be reprocessed when necessary.

For example, when an invoice is processed, all the extraction data returned by Document AI is stored in this column. You can then open this data and clearly see which fields Document AI has recognized.

In this article, we explored how to enable SAP Document AI on SAP BTP and integrate it end-to-end with a CAP project. Each stepâ€”from creating the service instance and generating the service key to authenticating, defining CAP actions, and processing documentsâ€”represents a fundamental building block of a real-world backend automation setup.With this integration, you can now automatically process invoices or similar business documents without manual data entry. The extracted fields can be stored in your HANA database and then used for reporting, process automation, or analytics. This approach not only speeds up financial and operational workflows but also reduces human error and increases overall process reliability.In production environments, this setup is typically secured and automated through service binding, allowing applications to read credentials from environment variables without manual configuration. This ensures smooth operation across development, test, and production landscapes.As a next step, you can extend this backend integration with a SAP UI5 dashboard or management panel, enabling users to upload, view, validate, and approve invoices in real time. By doing so, youâ€™ll move from a simple technical integration to a fully functional end-to-end intelligent document processing solution.

entry.title: Hands-on POC with SAP AI Core
entry.content:
Artificial Intelligence is transforming how we design and extend SAP applications. Many SAP professionals are now exploring how to start working with AI inside the SAP ecosystem.
In this post, I share my hands-on experience with SAP AI Core, from my first steps to building a real Proof of Concept (POC) using low-code tools like Build Apps and BPA.

Since May, Iâ€™ve been working on a POC with SAP AI Core. At that time, I knew nothing about AI. Step by step, by practicing with the examples and samples provided by SAP, I managed to build several POCs integrating SAP AI Core with low-code tools.

The main objective is simple: accelerate development cycles and innovate with custom applications. On my roadmap, I focused on using low-code solutions like SAP Build Apps and Process Automation (BPA), while integrating AI agents to speed up processes.

Maybe in a future post I will share more details about the POCs I realized. But today, my first goal is to encourage SAP technical consultants to start this journey.

As a Senior SAP Technical Consultant, I realized that integrating an AI agent for a first POC or when consuming partner models does not require brand-new skills. But if the objective is to build and train your own model, then of course new competences are needed.

With SAP AI Core, we can easily integrate partner models (like Azure OpenAI, ChatGPT, etc.) through APIs. For most SAP technical profiles, itâ€™s enough to follow a simple end-to-end example:

  • Select a partner model (text, image, etc.) in SAP AI Launchpad

  • Deploy it and get the URL

  • Configure the destination and start consuming your AI agent

Another option in SAP AI Launchpad is the Prompt Editor, which lets you create your own prompts on top of partner models. The key point here is security: your data is not stored in the model â€” itâ€™s managed securely by SAP.

This means that integrating external AI agents is feasible without heavy upskilling.

But in my opinion, the real power of SAP AI Core comes when you train your own models. Of course, this requires upskilling in new environments and languages. The key here is HANA Vector combined with RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation). Together, they enable customers to enrich their knowledge databases and build custom agents that are more efficient, optimized, and deliver a brilliant user experience.

I believe that SAP AI Core will become a central part of the future SAP landscape, enabling faster innovation and smarter business processes.

  Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts and experiences with SAP AI Core. Have you already built a POC or started exploring it?

Following a welcome long summer, Autumn has arrived and with it so have G2â€™s Fall badges. SAP BTP in our customersâ€™ words

Looking through these reviews however reveals some interesting statements, which perhaps gives some indication concerning why they rate SAP BTP so highly:

entry.title: New Partner Content on SAP Business Accelerator Hub (Q3 â€™25)
entry.content:
In continuation of our previous blog, we are excited to bring you the latest updates and maintain the momentum of delivering valuable insights to our community.

In this edition of our blog series, explore the newest content packages (particularly APIs and Integrations) released on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub by our partners in Q3 2025, along with their high-level details.

For complete details on each partner's content, refer to the partners listing which is available on the home page of SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Incture Technologies Private Limited

Integration packages published:

This package supports integration of business processes in your on-demand SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central system with your Third Party CSR Vendor - Benevity.

SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central with Third Party Benefits Vendor - Bswift

This package supports integration of business processes in your on-demand SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central system with your Third Party Benefits Vendor - Bswift

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

PiLog India Pvt Ltd

API package published:

PiLog Data Profiling

PiLog Data Profiling automates the process of examining and analyzing datasets to provide insights into their structure, quality, and content. It generates detailed HTML reports that highlight anomalies, missing values, patterns, and inconsistencies, enabling organizations to ensure data accuracy and suitability for use. This process is critical for data quality management, supporting data cleansing, validation, and preparation for advanced analytics or decision-making. By automating profiling, it minimizes manual effort, reduces errors, and accelerates data assessment for real-time insights.

ComZam Datentechnik GmbH

Integration package published:

The integration of SAP Customer Checkout with SAP S/4HANA Cloud features the replication of relevant master data to SAP Customer Checkout as well as posting Point of Sale transactions to SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Cobrainer GmbH

Integration package published:

This package contains artifacts that enable the various integration scenarios between SAP SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub and Cobrainer Job Architecture.

Navigate to the package mentioned above to know more about those supported integration scenarios.

Figaf ApS

The "Figaf Azure DevOps Integration" package provides a template for integrating Figaf and Azure. It includes highly configurable iFlows processing Figaf webhooks for ticket/transport events to Azure actions, update Figaf based on Azure changes, and a utility for searching issues.

The "Figaf Jira Integration" package provides a template for integrating Figaf and Jira. It includes highly configurable iFlows processing Figaf webhooks for ticket/transport events to Jira actions, update Figaf based on Jira changes, and a utility for searching issues.

Sodales Solutions Inc

Microsoft Booking Integration with SAP HANA

This package integrates with the Microsoft Booking API, enabling you to create and retrieve booking information. It helps streamline workflows, reduce manual tasks, and provide a unified experience across platforms.

Microsoft Teams Integration with SAP HANA

The Microsoft Graph API for Teams chat allows businesses to automate and integrate their Microsoft Teams chat functionality with a wide range of other applications and services. With this API, developers can programmatically send, receive, and manage chat messages within Teams, enabling seamless communication between systems and users.

Microsoft Mail Integration with SAP HANA

The Microsoft Graph API for email enables businesses to automate and integrate their email systems with various applications and services. It allows developers to programmatically access and manage email messages, folders, and attachments in Office 365 mailboxes.
