entry.title: SAP BTP Developer's Guide: Extending Fiori Elements with the Flexible Programming Model
entry.content:
Are you leveraging the full potential of SAP Fiori Elements' Flexible Programming Model in your enterprise applications? While this powerful capability has been available for sometime now, many developers are still discovering how to effectively implement its extension points, building blocks, and controller extensions to solve real-world business requirements.

If you've been curious about extending your Fiori elements applications beyond standard floorplans but weren't sure where to start, the SAP BTP Developer's Guide offers a comprehensive learning path that covers this and much more.
 

What is the Flexible Programming Model ?

 

The Flexible Programming Model offers an extensive toolkit for extending Fiori elements applications beyond standard floorplans. It provides multiple ways to customize and enhance your applications while maintaining enterprise standards and framework compliance.
The Flexible Programming Model encompasses four main areas:
  • Extension Points: including custom sections, actions, columns, header facets, dialogs, form elements, filters, pages, views, and KPI tags.
  • Building Blocks: reusable fields such as forms, tables, charts, filter bars, and specialized controls that maintain framework compliance. These are consistently orchestrated by the framework, ensuring you automatically benefit from SAP Fiori compliance and standard application behavior like draft handling and side effects.
  • Controller Extensions: for customizing edit flows, state handling, routing, navigation, and message handling - allowing you to override specific methods to enable more flexibility while preserving framework functionality.
  • SAP Fiori Elements Advanced Features: including sophisticated capabilities like Side Effects for dynamic UI behavior, UI.Hidden annotations for conditional visibility, UI.PartOfPreview annotations for optimized data loading, and enhanced Value Help configurations for improved user experience.
When using the Flexible Programming Model to extend your Fiori elements applications, you automatically preserve all the enterprise-ready features that SAP Fiori Elements provides out of the box:
  • Accessibility
  • Internationalization
  • Mobile Compatibility
  • Performance Optimizations
  • Integration
  • Security
  • Lifecycle Stability
  • Test Automation Support
  • UX Consistency
  • and much more ...
The key advantage is that the Flexible Programming Model allows you to add custom functionality while maintaining all these enterprise features that would otherwise require significant manual implementation and ongoing maintenance in freestyle development.

Complementary Development Approaches

 

The SAP BTP Developer's Guide provides clear recommendations for building Fiori applications that balance rapid development with flexibility needs. Rather than viewing these as competing alternatives, the guide positions them as complementary approaches that work together to deliver consistent, enterprise-grade solutions.
 
 
Use SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 to benefit from a presentation of a common UI and UX. This approach provides the foundation for rapid development while ensuring consistency across your application portfolio. Personalization and theming are automatically supported, giving users the flexibility they need without additional development effort.

For more flexibility, use SAP Fiori element's Flexible Programming Model with or without SAPUI5 Freestyle. This approach allows you to extend beyond standard capabilities while maintaining the benefits of the Fiori elements framework. The Flexible Programming Model serves as the bridge between standard floorplans and complete customization.

SAP Fiori elements and SAPUI5 help you present one consistent solution experience to your customers, and you benefit from the upcoming designs and UX improvements automatically. This means your applications evolve with the platform without requiring manual updates to maintain modern standards.

Important consideration: Remember that even the simplest UI components or more complex ones like geographic maps have compliance requirements like accessibility and theming. When extending beyond standard Fiori elements capabilities, these requirements must be carefully maintained to ensure enterprise-grade applications.
 

Enterprise-Grade Development on SAP BTP

 

The SAP BTP Developer's Guide serves as the comprehensive starting point for developing business applications on SAP Business Technology Platform. It provides essential recommendations and best practices that help developers navigate the complexities of enterprise application development.
 
Within this guide, the mission Develop an Enterprise-Grade CAP Application Following the SAP BTP Developer's Guide offers hands-on experience with critical enterprise development topics, including Change Tracking, Audit Logging, Attachments, Freestyle SAPUI5, Flexible Programming model and more.
 
While the mission covers multiple enterprise development aspects, the Flexible Programming Model section provides particularly valuable insights for developers looking to extend Fiori elements applications.
 
The learning scenarios are built around the Incident Management application, a practical business application where organizations can maintain and track incidents on behalf of their customers. This application already features a complete UI based on the SAP Fiori elements List Report Page floorplan, providing the perfect foundation to demonstrate how the Flexible Programming Model can enhance existing standard implementations.
The mission showcases several key extension capabilities that go beyond standard Fiori elements floorplans:
 
Extension Points: Custom Column
Learn to extend the Incidents table in the List Report Page with a custom column. This custom column demonstrates the integration of the MicroProcessFlow control, allowing processors to track incident progress directly within the table view.
 
 
Extension Points: Custom Header Facet
Discover how to enhance the header section in the Object Page by adding a custom header facet. This implementation showcases the MicroProcessFlow control in the header area, providing processors with immediate visibility into incident progress.
 
 
Extension Points: Custom Action
Implement a custom Location action in the Object Page that demonstrates practical integration of the GeoMap control. This custom action opens a dialog displaying customer locations, showing how to integrate specialized controls for business-specific functionality.
 
 
Extension Points: Custom Section
Add a comprehensive Process Flow custom section to the Object Page. This section demonstrates the implementation of the ProcessFlow control, providing detailed visualization of incident workflows and status transitions.
 
 
Controller Extension
Learn to extend the Fiori Elements Object Page controller to customize standard behaviors. This section demonstrates how to override the edit flow while maintaining framework compliance and enterprise standards.
 
 

Conclusion

The mission Develop an Enterprise-Grade CAP Application Following the SAP BTP Developer's Guide provides a comprehensive learning experience that goes beyond traditional tutorials. By combining Flexible Programming Model techniques with other essential enterprise development skills, you'll be equipped to build applications that meet real-world business requirements while maintaining the highest standards of enterprise software development.

Whether you're looking to extend existing Fiori elements applications or planning new enterprise solutions, this mission offers the practical, hands-on experience you need to master the art of enterprise application development on SAP BTP.
 
Happy Learning !

entry.title: MCP: A Comprehensive Guide
entry.content:
What Youâ€™ll Learn in this Guide

In this comprehensive guide to the Model Context Protocol (MCP), we explore how MCP simplifies AI integrations by standardizing the way AI systems connect with external tools and data sources.

By the end, youâ€™ll understand how MCP transforms complex, one-off integrations into a seamless, interoperable ecosystem.

Weâ€™ll cover:

Why MCP: The Problem with AI Integrations
What is MCP
MCP Architecture: Host, Client, and Server
Demo

1) Why MCP

To understand why the Model Context Protocol (MCP) matters, we need to trace the evolution from LLMs to AI Agents, and then to MCP as the missing interoperability layer.

1.1 The Problem with LLMs

While powerful, Large Language Models (LLMs) have four critical limitations:

Outdated knowledge
No access to external or real-time data
Limited context windows
Risks of hallucination

1.2 From LLMs to AI Agents

To overcome these challenges, AI Agents emerged â€” capable of accessing tools, invoking APIs, and making real-time decisions.

However, this evolution created a new problem: integration complexity.
Each AI agent or application needed custom integrations with multiple APIs, data sources, and tools â€” leading to fragmented, brittle connections.

1.3 The Problem with Agents Accessing Tools

In the traditional approach, every model must directly integrate with every tool â€” an MÃ—N problem.

Example:
3 AI models Ã— 3 tools = 9 separate connections.
Each integration is custom-built and non-reusable, resulting in a fragile and hard-to-maintain web of connections.

This approach doesnâ€™t scale. As the number of AI models and tools grows, integration overhead increases.

Solution â€” The MCP Approach

MCP replaces the MÃ—N complexity with a simple, scalable M+N model.

Each AI model and each tool integrates once with the MCP layer.
This single standard interface allows any AI model to access any tool seamlessly â€” without custom connectors.

In short, MCP turns AI integration from a one-off engineering effort into a plug-and-play ecosystem for tools, data, and intelligence.

2) What is MCP

MCP (Model Context Protocol) is an open-source standard that defines how AI applications communicate with external systems through a unified interface.

It enables interoperability between different AI agents, tools, and platforms â€” regardless of their language, framework, or runtime environment.

With MCP, developers can build AI solutions that dynamically discover and invoke new tools securely and consistently.

3) MCP Architecture: Host, Client, and Server

MCP follows a client-server architecture similar to web protocols, but tailored for AI interaction.

It consists of three main components:

MCP Host â€” Manages and exposes available tools

MCP Client â€” Initiates requests to discover and use tools

MCP Server â€” Implements tool capabilities and exposes them to clients

3.1 MCP Server core capabilities

3.2 Interaction Model

The following diagram illustrates the interaction between the Host, MCP Server, and MCP Client.

This modular structure allows AI systems to dynamically discover, invoke, and orchestrate tools through a standardized layer â€” without direct coupling between tools and models.

3.3 Real-World Example: SAP MCP Servers

SAP has released MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers for CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model), UI5, and Fiori development environments.

With these MCP servers, AI agents can now assist developers contextually â€” understanding project structure, metadata, and domain models to offer precise, real-time help in CAP, Fiori, and UI5 projects.

This demonstrates how MCP can be embedded into enterprise ecosystems, bridging AI assistance with actual business development workflows.

4) Demo

The following demo illustrates these concepts in action:
https://github.com/pramodkumarmangu/mcp-demo

Demo 1 shows the integration challenges without MCP.
Demo 2 demonstrates how MCP simplifies integration and tool discovery through a unified protocol.

These demos make the shift from manual, fragile integrations to MCP-driven automation immediately clear.

Key Takeaways

MCP simplifies AI integrations by replacing point-to-point connections with a single standard interface.
Interoperability is built-in â€” any AI agent can use any MCP-compliant tool.
Scalability improves as new tools or models can be added without re-engineering integrations.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in September
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in September

Another month with two nice new release deliveries âœ¨

Learn more in my short top features video in September 2025 on YouTube ðŸ“º

In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and more.

â€ƒ

My top features in September

 

Input Parameters in Task Chains and Transformation Flows

You can now define input parameters on the task level of task chains and also for transformation flows. A scheduled transformation flow uses the default value of the input parameter. Input parameters defined in transformation flows can be used in operators within the transformation flow, except for the Python operation in Apache Spark runtime.

A transformation flow executed as part of a task chain receives input parameters from the task chain. This will allow for more flexible usage of task chains and even nested task chains.

âž¡ï¸  Creating a Transformation Flow

âž¡ï¸  Creating Input Parameters in Task Chains

 

Email notification in Replication Flows

You can setup email notifications to stay informed when individual replication objects fail in a running replication flow. From both the Replication Flow editor or the Flows monitor, you can setup an email notification for failures of an individual object in a replication flow.

âž¡ï¸  Configure Email Notification for Replication Flow Failure at Object Level

âž¡ï¸  Working With Existing Replication Flow Runs

 

Fiscal Time Dimension

When creating a time dimension view, you now have the option for dimension type Standard and Fiscal Time. You use the new Fiscal Time dimension type to model your fiscal time periods and the columns that define their starts and ends. When you add a fiscal time dimension to an analytic model, a Fiscal Variant variable is created for this dimension. The variable can then be handled like any other variable. Its data type is derived from the fiscal variance column from the fiscal time dimension.

âž¡ï¸  More information

 

Structure Support for Analytic Models

In order to create restrictions and calculations across all measures of an analytic model, you can create structures. Structures help you to save time and ensure consistency in your calculations, as you donâ€™t need to create a formula/calculation for each measure. In the data preview, the structure members are displayed in their own section. When you use a structure member in the drill-down of a preview, the restriction and calculations defined in the structure member will be applied to each measure. Structures can also be used and enhanced in SAP Analytics Cloud. When the analytic model has measures and at least one structure you need to define how the calculations should be prioritized.

âž¡ï¸  More information

 

 

SAP Business Data Cloud Getting Started Series

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite: Whatâ€™s New in Q3/2025
entry.content:
Another quarter has come to an end and itâ€™s time for us to review the most recent updates and improvements delivered to SAP Integration Suite. Whether youâ€™re an integration architect, developer, or business leader, these new features are designed to help you get the most out of your hybrid landscape. Read on to discover whatâ€™s new and how these enhancements can support your organisationâ€™s integration goals.

Message status overview monitoring for large tenants

One awaited featured has been released to the Cloud Integration capability of SAP Integration Suite to improve Message Status Overview monitoring and support larger time intervals through data preaggregation. Now the monitoring option can be utilized for extended periods on tenants with a high volume of message processing logs.

Artificial Intelligence

AI-based integration flow generation with mediation steps

Earlier this year, the generation of integration flows with the assistance of AI was made available to customers. This enable users to generate an integration flow with sender and receiver systems based on a scenario description provided in natural language. You can read more about it here.

In Q3/2025 we have enhanced this feature to include additional mediation steps. This means that now, users can provide even more detailed scenarios and the tool identifies the details and generates a comprehensive integration flow with the described components, systems, and actions. Get a first glimpse into how to use this feature in the blog post: SAP Integration Suite â€“ Generative AI based Integration Flow Generation with Mediation Steps.

 Business Accelerators

Joule copilot-based conversational search and discovery of content

Joule has arrived at the SAP Business Accelerator Hub in Q3 to help users find the right content throughconversational context-based search. The Joule-based discovery provides user guidance to search different artifacts and access cohesive information for other relevant sources, such as help documentation.

Note: The feature is currently in the beta phase and you can find more details on availability here.  

Connectivity and Adapters

The latest releases of SAP Integration Suite introduced a new array of adapters and connectors designed to streamline and enhance connectivity, improve data flow, and foster a more integrated digital landscape for businesses leveraging SAP solutions.

AI adapter

The recently released AI adapter for SAP Integration Suite functions as a receiver adapter and accelerates connectivity to the Generative AI Hub (SAP AI Core) and other AI providers, as needed by customer (BYOM).

 The benefit of this adapter is that it increases connectivity options to integrate with both SAP and third-party systems and applications. How it works: after configuration, data exchange is performed at runtime where the SAP Integration Suite tenant sends the operation request to GenAIHub. The AI Adapter works on the request and sends the data back to the SAP Integration Suite tenant.

Find the AI Adapter at SAP Business Accelerator Hub, read the help documentation, and check out the short demo below:

Further adapters released in Q3 include:

IBM MQ adapter using JMS protocol: client certificate supportSupports Client Certificate based authentication for JMS Variants. A new version 1.3.0 of the IBM MQ adapter supports Client Certificate based authentication for JMS Variants.- Configure the IBM MQ JMS Receiver Adapter
IBM MQ adapter using JMS protocol: client certificate supportSupports On-Premise Connectivity via Cloud Connector for JMS Variants. A new version 1.4.0 of the IBM MQ adapter supports On-Premise Connectivity via Cloud Connector for JMS Variants.

- Configure the IBM MQ JMS Sender Adapter

- Configure the IBM MQ JMS Receiver Adapter
BigCommerce adapterFacilitates the connectivity to BigCommerce GraphQL & REST Admin APIs, accelerates the implementation time and reduces complexity of connecting to BigCommerce. This adapter is available on SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

- BigCommerce Adapter at SAP Business Accelerator Hub

- BigCommerce Receiver Adapter

ðŸš€ðŸš€Discover the latest content packages, including APIs and Integrations, released on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub by our partners in Q3 2025. These releases come with high-level details to help you understand their features and benefits.

API-Centric & Event-Driven Integrations

Support for reusable API artifacts in Edge Integration Cell

Customers can now leverage components, endpoints, and services across multiple applications, projects, or contexts, without having to perform significant adaptations. The reusability of API artifacts enables companies to implement a centralized security and traffic management system for exposed APIs. It not only enhances compliance and reduces misconfiguration risks but also significantly lowers both the total cost of development and ownership by eliminating redundant configurations and promoting the reuse of existing API artifacts, which means additional API calls are avoided, leading to cost savings. Learn more.

 

Watch the demo from this year's Devtoberfest - Session "Next generation hybrid integration with Edge Integration Cell":

Integration of Advanced Event Mesh with SAP Cloud Application Event Hub

The latest updates allow you to connect your SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh system to SAP Cloud Application Event Hub for the consumption and exposure of events.

SAP Cloud Application Event Hub creates a clear, user-friendly, and adaptable way to easily exchange business events across SAP's cloud landscape. The solution is a key part of SAP's event-driven architecture. With the integration, you can access events from various SAP business systems, published via the hub, directly on SAP Integration Suite's advanced event mesh.

Migration & Modernization

ABAP proxy generation from service interfaces for current users of SAP Process Orchestration

SAP Integration Suite now supports the implementation of existing use cases for the Enterprise Services Repository using an efficient API-first development methodology. This assists users in importing the service interface artifacts from their PI/PO systems to the Cloud Integration workspace. The feature includes the ability to generate and update ABAP Proxies (non-language-specific interface descriptions in Web Services Description Language converted into executable interfaces) in SAP backend or S/4 HANA systems by connecting them to the SAP Integration Suite tenant and itâ€™s available in the multi-cloud environment. Find more details and the prerequisites here.

Migration assessment: Clean core modernization recommendations for BAPIs

This extension of the Migration Assessment capability in SAP Integration Suite makes it possible for users to analyse used BAPIs in SAP Process Orchestration. Additionally, they receive recommendations available in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub to transition from legacy content and adopt a clean core approach, e.g. replacing RFCs (BAPIs) with SOAP/OData APIs, IDOCs with Business Events, Alert Rules by SAP Cloud ALM, and more. Explore all modernization recommendations covered in each area.

Dive Deeper

New learning offerings available

Accelerating Hybrid Integrations with SAP Integration Suite on SUSE Rancher Set up, deploy, and operate Edge Integration Cell on SUSE Rancher Kubernetes EngineTime investment 3h, Record of achievement
Accelerating Hybrid Integrations with SAP Integration Suite on RedHat OpenShift Set up, deploy, and run an Edge Integration Cell on Red Hat OpenShiftTime investment 3h, Record of achievement
Exploring Enterprise Automation with SAPUnderstand how SAP Signavio, SAP Build, and SAP Integration Suite work together to improve efficiency and responsiveness Time investment 1.5h, Record of achievement

Whatâ€™s next?

  • Integration @ Devtoberfest: watch all sessions
  • Join us at SAP TechEd 2025: explore the Integration track and register

entry.title: SAP S4 HANA Finance integration and Use case with SAP Joule
entry.content:
What Is SAP Joule?

SAP Joule is SAPâ€™s AI copilot embedded across its cloud applications. It offers four interaction typesâ€”Transactional, Navigational, Informational, and Analyticalâ€”that let users perform business tasks via natural language within SAP environments. It understands user context, roles, permissions, and remains secure by design. It can also ground responses in your own business documents.

 How SAP Joule works in Public vs. Private Cloud is one of the most important considerations for finance teams (especially in FICO) deciding on adoption.

Hereâ€™s a structured view:

 SAP Joule in Public vs. Private Cloud

Deployment & Integration

  • Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)
    • Joule is natively embedded and updated by SAP automatically.
    • Integration with SAP FICO apps (GL, AP, AR, Asset Accounting, Controlling) is out of the box.
    • No additional installation required - users just activate and configure.
  • Private Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition)
    • Joule can be enabled, but may require additional setup and integration.
    • Some Joule features might lag behind public cloud, because public gets innovations first.
    • Still integrates with FICO, but might require extra configuration & tenant connections to SAP BTP.

Feature Availability

  • Public Cloud
    • Joule supports all 4 interaction types (Transactional, Navigational, Informational, Analytical) directly in Fiori apps.
    • Example in FICO: â€œPost vendor invoiceâ€ â†’ transaction executes directly.
    • Faster delivery of Joule Agents and Joule Studio.
  • Private Cloud
    • Informational & Analytical features available early (queries, reports, insights).
    • Transactional flows may require enablement through custom skills/agents.
    • Joule Studio can still be connected via SAP BTP, but adoption speed depends on customerâ€™s upgrade cycle.

Customization & Extensibility

  • Public Cloud
    • Limited custom codingâ€”extensions must go through SAP BTP side-by-side development.
    • Joule skills/agents are mostly standardized.
    • Great if you want speed & standardization.
  • Private Cloud
    • More flexibility: you can create custom FICO processes, reports, and Joule agents.
    • Easier to integrate with on-prem or legacy systems.
    • Suited for companies with complex finance processes.

Data Security & Residency

  • Public Cloud
    • Data is hosted on SAP-managed hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, GCP, SAP DCs).
    • Joule queries financial data via secure APIs; customers rely on SAPâ€™s compliance.
  • Private Cloud
    • You control hosting, location, and more of the security stack.
    • Some finance-heavy industries (banking, defense, public sector) may prefer this for regulatory reasons.

Upgrade & Innovation

  • Public Cloud
    • Quarterly upgrades â†’ Joule features arrive first and fastest.
    • Example: New Joule Agents for FICO tasks (like dispute resolution) appear immediately.
  • Private Cloud
    • Annual upgrades (with optional Feature Packs).
    • Joule features arrive laterâ€”innovation follows public cloud by a few cycles.

 Comparison Table

Aspect

Public Cloud

Private Cloud

Availability

Native, out-of-the-box

Needs setup, later adoption

Updates

Quarterly, fastest innovations

Annual/controlled upgrades

Customization

Limited, BTP-based

Flexible, deep customizations

Security

SAP-managed hyperscalers

Customer-controlled

FICO Use Cases

Immediate transactional & analytical support

Strong for complex, regulated finance scenarios

Joule Studio

Fully available

Available via BTP, more flexible

 Which is Better for FICO?

  • Public Cloud â†’ Best if you want rapid innovation, standard finance processes, faster AI adoption.
  • Private Cloud â†’ Best if you need deep customization, strict compliance, hybrid IT integration.

 SAP Joule version requirements for S/4HANA Cloud editions (Public and Private):

  1. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Joule arrived as part of the Public Cloud starting around Q3 2024, and is embedded in all releases thereafter, including 2408 (August 2024) and onward.
  • While Joule is built into these releases, you still need proper entitlement and authorization to use it; this may require activation via your SAP admin or account executive.
  • There are setup guides available detailing how to activate Joule once entitlement is granted.

In Summary:

If your system is on Public Cloud release 2408 (Aug 2024) or later, Joule is already supportedâ€”assuming you've got the right access and permissions.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

  • Joule is available in the Private Cloud as well, but requires setup and configuration. It's not automatically activeâ€”you must enable it via SAP BTP and Joule Studio.
  • Technical prerequisites include ensuring the UI5 version in your system meets or exceeds the minimum required for Joule integration. The specific UI5 version will depend on your release; you can consult SAP documentation for exact details.

In Summary:

Private Cloud systems can support Jouleâ€”but you must set it up, ensure the UI5 stack is compatible, and configure the feature via BTP.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise (Classic)

  • Joule is not supported on on-premise S/4HANA. SAP has confirmed it's not on the current roadmap for classic on-premise systems.
  • Thereâ€™s a planned strategyâ€”possibly coming Q1 2025â€”to enable Joule via SAP Build Work Zone, BTP, and Joule Studio even for on-prem systems. But as of now, Joule remains unavailable on-prem and unsupported.

High-Level Overview

Edition

Supported from (release)

Requirements

Public Cloud

2408 (Aug 2024) onward

Needs entitlement/authorization & activation

Private Cloud

Post-2024 releases

Requires UI5 prerequisites + BTP/Joule Studio setup

On-Premise (classic)

Not supported (as of now)

No Joule availability; roadmap may include future BTP-based solution

Summary:

  • Public Cloud: Joule is supported starting with 2408 onwardâ€”activate it via entitlement.
  • Private Cloud: Joule is available but not automaticâ€”requires UI compliance + setup via BTP.
  • On-Premise: Joule is not supported yet; no built-in version availability.

Hereâ€™s how SAP Joule, SAPâ€™s generative AI assistant, can be applied specifically within the SAP FICO (Finance & Controlling) domain:

SAP Joule Application in FICO

  • Transactional Interactions

Joule allows users to perform CRUD operations and manage financial documents via natural languageâ€”imagine asking:

  • â€œPost a vendor invoice of $5,000 to account X with due date Y.â€
  • â€œShow me the status of PO invoice 10234.â€
    While SAP hasn't yet released out-of-the-box FICO conversational flows, Jouleâ€™s transactional model supports this kind of interaction across cloud applications.
  • Navigational Interactions

Instead of navigating through menus to reach Fiori apps like â€œDisplay GL Account Balances,â€ you could simply ask:

  • â€œWhere can I review G/L balances?â€
    Joule will direct you to the relevant screen.
  • Informational Interactions

Straight answers instead of digging through help docs. You can ask:

  • â€œWhatâ€™s the difference between cost center and profit center accounting?â€
  • â€œExplain account determination for automatic postings.â€
    Joule will deliver concise explanations, referencing SAP documentation or your own policy documents.

Analytical Interactions

Joule bridges your natural-language queries to data analytics:

  • â€œShow me quarterly expense trends per cost center.â€
  • â€œWhich cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?â€
    It returns charts, metrics, or dashboardsâ€”leveraging SAP Analytics Cloud integration.

Advanced: Joule Agents & Studio

Joule Agents

SAP has introduced AI agentsâ€”autonomous actors capable of executing complex, multi-step workflows across business functions. In FICO, custom agents could:

  • Automate dispute resolution: Collaborate across finance and service teams to validate discrepancies and propose corrections.
  • Cash collection workflows: Analyze overdue invoices, coordinate with collections, and initiate follow-ups.
    These agents are part of SAPâ€™s cross-functional automation strategy.

Joule Studio (within SAP Build)

No-code/low-code tool to create custom skills or agents tailored for your FICO needs:

  • Build a skill to automatically generate internal financial reports, or trigger approval workflows.
  • Automate vendor reconciliation or recurring postings by designing tailored AI agents.
    These skills and agents integrate across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Summary Table

Joule Capability

FICO Use Case Example

Transactional

Post invoices, check payment status via natural language

Navigational

Ask â€œWhere to view Cost Center Reports?â€

Informational

Clarify financial terms or posting rules

Analytical

Generate trends and KPI charts using SAC

Agents & Studio

Automate dispute resolution, cash collection, approvals

Key Benefits in FICO

  • Boost Productivity: Save time by speaking instead of clicking through screens.
  • Reduce Errors: Leverage conversational clarity and auto-generated documents.
  • Improve Insights: Conduct data reviews and root cause analysis through simple dialogue.
  • Automate Complex Workflows: Agents handle multi-step tasks such as reconciliations or approvals automatically.

Real-World Usage Context -- Caveats

While SAP is rapidly developing Jouleâ€™s capabilities, many implementations remain in pilot or PoC stages. Users in forums report limited early usage, primarily for basic navigation or queries.

Here are concrete FICO scenarios where you could pilot SAP Joule and even extend it with Joule Agents / Studio:

 Pilot Scenarios in SAP FICO

  1. Invoice & Payment Handling
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œPost an invoice for vendor ABC with $12,000 due in 30 days.â€
  • Joule Action: Creates the posting, validates tax code, and confirms with you.
  • Extension with Agent: Automate follow-upâ€”if payment not cleared by due date, Joule Agent triggers a reminder email or escalates.
  1. Month-End Close Assistant
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œWhat are the pending tasks for month-end close?â€
  • Joule Action: Lists open items (accruals, GR/IR clearing, reconciliations).
  • Extension with Agent: Automate recurring accrual postings and send alerts to approvers who are late in providing confirmations.
  1. Financial Analysis & Insights
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œShow me expense trend per cost center for last 6 months.â€
  • Joule Action: Returns a chart (via SAC integration).
  • Extension with Agent: Forecast next quarterâ€™s expenses and flag cost centers that may exceed budgets.
  1. Audit & Compliance Checks
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œList journal entries above $50,000 in the last quarter without approvals.â€
  • Joule Action: Generates a filtered list.
  • Extension with Agent: Create an automated internal audit agent that periodically checks for compliance exceptions and notifies controllers.
  1. Treasury & Cash Management
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œWhat is todayâ€™s cash position?â€
  • Joule Action: Summarizes bank balances, incoming/outgoing payments.
  • Extension with Agent: Auto-generate a daily treasury dashboard at 9 AM and send to CFO.
  1. Dispute & Collections Management
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œShow me customers with invoices overdue > 60 days.â€
  • Joule Action: Lists overdue accounts.
  • Extension with Agent: An AI agent sends personalized payment reminders and schedules calls with collections staff.
  1. Budget vs. Actual Control
  • Ask Joule:
    â€œWhich cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?â€
  • Joule Action: Shows variances with drill-down.
  • Extension with Agent: Automatically notify budget owners when variances exceed a threshold (say 10%).

 How to Design in Joule Studio

In Joule Studio (within SAP Build) you can:

  1. Create a Skill â†’ â€œGenerate quarterly P&L by company code and send PDF to finance team.â€
  2. Create an Agent â†’ â€œMonitor overdue vendor payments and auto-initiate dunning.â€
  3. Connect Non-SAP Apps â†’ e.g., send approvals via MS Teams or Slack.

 

 This way, Joule moves from a copilot (answering queries) to a colleague (executing finance tasks for you).

 

Deep Dive on one of the real-world example: Vendor Invoice Posting with SAP Joule in Public vs Private Cloud.

 Example: Vendor Invoice Posting with Joule

 Scenario

A finance user wants to post a vendor invoice for Vendor 300012, amount $12,000, due in 30 days.

 Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)

  • User says to Joule:
    â€œPost a vendor invoice of $12,000 for Vendor 300012, due in 30 days.
  • Joule Process:
    1. Understands the intent (â€œCreate Vendor Invoiceâ€).
    2. Pulls relevant master data (Vendor 300012 details, tax code, payment terms).
    3. Pre-fills the invoice screen in Fiori.
    4. User confirms â†’ Invoice is posted.
  • Extras in Public Cloud:
    • Joule can immediately display the document number and due date schedule.
    • If connected to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), Joule can also show how this impacts cash outflow forecast.
    • Minimal setup â†’ available out-of-the-box.

 Private Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition)

  • User says to Joule:
     â€œPost a vendor invoice of $12,000 for Vendor 300012, due in 30 days.â€
  • Joule Process:
    • Provide navigation â†’ â€œOpen FB60 (Vendor Invoice Entry)â€ or â€œFiori App: Create Supplier Invoice.â€
    • Pre-fill metadata only if integrated with custom Joule Skill via Joule Studio.
    1. Joule recognizes intent, but instead of direct posting, it may:
    2. User manually confirms or adjusts in the classic posting screen (e.g., FB60 / MIRO).
    3. Invoice is posted.
  • Extras in Private Cloud:
    • You can customize Joule Agent (via Joule Studio + BTP) to enforce company-specific validations (e.g., block invoices >$10,000 without 2 approvals).
    • Joule can connect to legacy non-SAP apps (like OCR invoice scanners or in-house workflow systems).
    • Requires more setup & governance compared to Public Cloud.

 Side-by-Side Comparison

Step

Public Cloud

Private Cloud

Activation

Native, plug-and-play

Needs setup & integration

Invoice Posting

Joule executes directly in Fiori app

Joule suggests navigation, may require custom agent for automation

Data Validation

Standard rules auto-applied

Flexible, can embed custom compliance rules

User Effort

Minimal (voice/text â†’ posted)

Moderate (confirmation in screen, extra steps if no custom agent)

Analytics

Immediate cash flow impact via SAC

Possible, but may need manual SAC integration

Customization

Limited (SAP-standard process)

Flexible (custom workflows, approvals, legacy integration)

Key Takeaway:

  • In Public Cloud, Joule = speed + simplicity â†’ perfect for companies with standard finance processes.
  • In Private Cloud, Joule = control + flexibility â†’ better if you need extra compliance steps, custom posting logic, or hybrid integration.

entry.title: BTP Trial Update: CF Runtime Availability
entry.content:
Dear SAP BTP trial community,

 
We always aimed to give users the most freedom and flexibility in the SAP BTP trial to ensure that everyone can test and explore our software or use it for learning purposes. For the next weeks, the SAP BTP trial will not be able to deliver this experience for new SAP BTP trial accounts as we have to prioritize the security and reliability of our SAP BTP trial system. We are experiencing an unusually high amount of misuse limiting the availability for all of our users. 
 
Therefore, we decided to temporarily reduce the offering for the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry runtime for new BTP Trial Accounts. You will still be able to build applications and preview them, but deployment in the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry runtime will not be possible for the next weeks. 
 
How can you still explore SAP BTP? 
  • All other services will remain available and can be explored on the SAP Discovery Center
  • Leverage our SAP Basic trial offerings 
  • As a partner: Refer to our newly released free TDD licenses
  • As a customer: Leverage the free tier offering as part of Pay-As-You-Go for SAP BTP available in the SAP Store
 

All updates will be posted in the SAP Community. 

If you have an existing account, you are not affected. 
 
See you soon, 
SAP BTP trial product team
